title: An aperiodic monotile

last_post.content:
Wow!! What a breathe of fresh air this paper is in the midst of suffocating levels of "AI solves everything" hype cycle.

https://arxiv.org/abs/2303.10798

They have found at long last, a single tile, an "einstein", which they call a "hat"/polykite that tiles the entire plane aperiodically.

Previously the best known aperiodic tiling of the plane required at the least two different tiles, the most famous ones being the Penrose tiles, and those that adorn Alhambra.

It is all the more wonderful that the first two authors don't have any academic/research affiliations. They write somewhere in the paper, how it all started, so wonderful:

"One of the authors (Smith) began investigating the hat polykite as part of his open-ended visual exploration of shapes and their tiling properties. Working largely by hand, with the assistance of Scherphuis’s PolyForm Puzzle Solver software (www.jaapsch.net/puzzles/polysolver.htm), he could find no obvious barriers to the construction of large patches, and yet no clear cluster of tiles that filled the plane periodically."

Why is the study of tilings such a big deal? Well, it hints at and tries to formalize various physics concepts that are of immense interest to many of us (and dare I say, even neuroscientists): quasi crystals!, possible new states of matter, emergent structures from simple units, how symmetries and asymmetries arise, stability of heterogenous media, soft matter physics, order without periodicity, criticality etc., etc.,

On quasi-crystals and their search, applications, uses etc., I recommend the wonderful Paul Steinhardt's book: "The Second Kind of Impossible: The Extraordinary Quest for a New Form of Matter"

#Physics #Maths #Combinatorics #AperiodicTiling #PenroseTiles #Einstein #Emergence #condensedmatter

title: OpenAI’s policies hinder reproducible research on language models

last_post.content:
Language models have become privately controlled research infrastructure. This week, OpenAI deprecated the Codex model that ~100 papers have used—with 3 days’ notice. It has said that newer models will only be stable for 3 months. Goodbye reproducibility!

It'll be interesting to see how developers are going to use these models in production if things are going to break every couple of months.

By @sayashk and me on the AI Snake Oil book blog: https://aisnakeoil.substack.com/p/openais-policies-hinder-reproducible

last_post.content:

title: An important next step on our AI journey

last_post.content:
I've been puzzled at why Google Bard seems to be much less capable than Bing - for example it seems much more prone to hallucination when it should be using facts it pulls in from Google search

Turns out it's built on Google's cheaper, less powerful model!

> We’re releasing it initially with our lightweight model version of LaMDA. This much smaller model requires significantly less computing power, enabling us to scale to more users, allowing for more feedback

https://blog.google/technology/ai/bard-google-ai-search-updates/

title: https://wordpress.org/plugins/activitypub/

last_post.content:
Are you sitting down? Here goes!

44% of all websites that exist right now run on WordPress.

Right now, connecting a WordPress site to the Fediverse is just a matter of installing this plug-in.

If just a fraction of WordPress sites connect to ActivityPub, then the network effect of the Fediverse will eclipse Big Social.

title: https://arxiv.org/pdf/2210.10523.pdf

last_post.content:
Popular messaging apps like #WhatsApp and #Signal notify the sender when a message has been delivered.

Did you know that you can use this RTT (Round Trip Time) to triangulate the geographic location of the receiver?

Join me in today's episode of #WhitepaperWednesday as we explore the tactics of extracting user locations from mobile instant messengers.

https://arxiv.org/pdf/2210.10523.pdf

Shoutout to the brilliant minds behind this paper, none of which I could find on Mastodon🫤 :

Theodor Schnitzler

Katharina Kohls (birdsite@blister_green)

Evangelos Bitsikas

Christina Popper (birdsite@XtinaPoepper)

title: 10 million Mastodon accounts

last_post.content:
Mastodon has reached the milestone of 10 million accounts! 🎉

10M Mastodon accounts is great, but what does that exactly measure? And according to whom? One side effect of being a decentralized network is that usage and activity is hard to measure. In this article I take a look at the different data sources that count Mastodon account numbers, and some of the open questions regarding which number is actually correct.

Read more at: https://fediversereport.com/10-million-mastodon-accounts/

[LLMs = large language models]

On the difference between speaking and thinking (and humans and machines)

title: This Georgia County Spent $1 Million to Avoid Paying for One Employee’s Gender-Affirming Care

last_post.content: Our reporting for @ProPublica included reviewing state employee health plans in all 50 states + DC -- these 15 states had health plans in 2022 that specifically excluded coverage of gender-affirming medical care. In several lawsuits, federal judges have ruled the exclusions were discriminatory and ordered states like NC and WI to remove their exclusions. https://www.propublica.org/article/georgia-county-spent-one-million-fighting-coverage-gender-affirming-care

title: It’s Game Over on Vocal Deepfakes

last_post.content: Unfortunately, @gruber is right not just about computer-generated synthesized audio, but all media. Our society does not have enough information literacy enough to separate truth from bullshit, and neither does our news media: “Real recordings will be called fake and fake recordings will be leaked as purportedly real. I don’t think the general population is prepared for this, and I worry that news media organizations aren’t either.” https://daringfireball.net/2023/03/game_over_vocal_deepfakes

title: https://biclar.tmlmobilidade.pt

last_post.content:
I'm super excited to present #biclaR a tool to assist cities to plan cycling networks based on its potential to transfer trips from car 🚗 🌱💰
It is all in #foos and was developed with @robinlovelace and the Universities of Lisbon and Leeds for the Metropolitan Department of Transportation of Lisbon. Have a look (Portuguese) in 👉 https://biclar.tmlmobilidade.pt #rstats #gis #opensouce #cycling #planning

title: cran.r-project.org/package=deb...

last_post.content:
I’m really happy to announce that my #rstats package for working with historical non-decimal currencies and other non-decimal value systems, debkeepr, is finally on CRAN. The release has been a long time in the making. I will have more to say soon, including a blog post, but I wanted to mark the packages acceptance on CRAN 🎉. #rstats #DigitalHumanities #DigitalHistory #histodons

https://cran.r-project.org/package=debkeepr

title: dplyr 1.1.1

last_post.content:
dplyr 1.1.1 is on CRAN! 🎉 #rstats

This release includes two important updates:
- Addressing performance regressions, particularly with `case_when()`
- Refining the `multiple` match join warning

You should see significantly fewer warnings about multiple matches during joins now!

https://www.tidyverse.org/blog/2023/03/dplyr-1-1-1/

title: Play | Placemark

last_post.content:
Map editing tool Placemark released Placemark Play, a free and no-login, web based map editor https://app.placemark.io/play I have been using Placemark for a couple of projects, and it is absolutely great. Copying the features list here:

- Create maps from scratch by drawing geospatial data
- Do analysis like buffers, simplification, measuring areas
- Import & export in many formats
- Edit your geospatial data in a flexible table view
- Prototype & export data-driven Mapbox GL & Leaflet styles

title: Tracking the Chinese Balloon From Space

last_post.content:
Tracking the Chinese Balloon From Space https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2023/03/20/science/chinese-space-balloon-incident.html AI was able to find the balloon in terrabytes of Planet satellite imagery, up to the Chinese coast

Great work by the New York Times graphics team, and by my soon-to-be colleague at Planet @rsimmon Hope to contribute to stories like this soon!

Here is a Planet article with some background: https://www.planet.com/pulse/one-more-way-ai-can-help-us-harness-one-of-the-most-underutilized-datasets-in-the-world/

title: Twitter Study Tracker – After the 2022 Takeover

last_post.content:
I added 4 studies on post-takeover Twitter to my tracker, bringing the total to 11.

Some new points to highlight: It's not just hate speech & far-right engagement that's increasing over there.

Misinformation superspreaders' tweets are booming - & mainstream media Twitter accounts have only had a small decline in engagement. Which is why they're staying, I guess.

I wonder if they'll keep their blue checks & associated benefits - & what will happen if they don't.
1/3

https://statistically-funny.blogspot.com/p/twitter-study-tracker-after-2022.html

title: Mobile home parks offer refuge from California’s housing squeeze. Who’s watching them?

last_post.content:
What do some residents of California's mobile home parks deal with? Lots of shit. Figurative and literal shit.

According to amazing reporting from my @CalMatters colleague Manuela Tobias earlier this week:

"The worst for residents were the pools of putrid brown liquid they have had to wade through, on and off, for nearly four years."

https://calmatters.org/housing/2023/03/mobile-home-parks-california-housing/

title: Bike Helmet Ratings

last_post.content:
So impressed by the Virginia Tech team that does scientific tests of bicycle helmets. Their new research is out and they are using targeted ads to reach consumers with this important safety information.

The VT team has defied many mistaken assumptions / norms in academia to save many lives with science

https://www.helmet.beam.vt.edu/bicycle-helmet-ratings.html

title: How Attacks Against Obamacare Turned Into Tools to Protect Abortion Access  - Bolts

last_post.content:
Big news: a judge just blocked Wyoming's abortion ban.

Why? Because of language that *conservatives* put in the WY constitution last decade to enshrine health care choice... as their way to attack Obamacare.

We explained that legal twist, & why you should see it coming, last week in @bolts! https://boltsmag.org/abortion-access-and-measures-against-obamacare-ohio-wyoming/

title: Smoke screen

last_post.content: Mandy Brown is always brilliant, but today’s essay on the stories that the tech industry tells itself about AI and what they indicate about its underlying worldview is, phew. Come for the razor-sharp analysis of the power of metaphor, stay for the dissection of how the dominant definition of intelligence is used as a tool for perpetuating systemic inequities. https://aworkinglibrary.com/writing/smoke-screen

title: How the Last-Ditch Effort to Save Silicon Valley Bank Failed

last_post.content:
Today's Matt Levine newsletter, recapping WSJ reporting that SVB's collapse was due in part to Fed systems – which are necessary for large transfers like the $20B SVB would have needed – becoming inaccessible (by design!) at 4pm, and not being reachable until the following morning. 🤯😱

Original WSJ report: https://www.wsj.com/articles/how-the-last-ditch-effort-to-save-silicon-valley-bank-failed-89619cb2
